doc.after: A detached, cylindrical Tudor tower stands immediately to the southeast of the house, and is generally considered to be the earliest part of the building;[5] however, Lysons believes it to have been a later addition.[4] The tower is built of local red brick, and is 21 feet (6.4Â m) tall, with walls 3 feet (0.91Â m) thick.[5] In 2006, excavations revealed that it continues for some distance below the current ground level.[6] It was described in 1829 as being over a deep well, and being used as a dairy.[7]
